content.body: "I'm not going to go all 'hixie' on your asses." -- shane mccarron, http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdfa-wg/2010Oct/0239.html
I'm not convinced that's a good thing
hober: if that isn't him "going hixie" i wonder what "going hixie" looks like
Probably involves more three-level step-by-step algorithms
Dashiva: something tells me that's not what he meant
Hixie: indeed
perhaps he meant it involves writing good specs in general
ones that address market needs
and solve real problems
and generally getting shit done ;)
I think the sound of "Ostanite mirni i stvorili stvari." is beautiful
that is the best-sounding way to say it in any language I have tried so far
MikeSmith: that sounds like R2D2-speak to me :|
heh
"stvo" and "stva" are great ways to start words
wow, that's totally innapropriate
google translate reckons it's serbian - cute!
google translate usually does a pretty good job at guessing
I wonder how much it reads in and analyzes before it makes a determination
Mechanical Turk :)
nessy: you reported your crasher?
fantasai: ping
fantasai: wondering what i should do about invalid font test...
remove it or stub it out?
HTML parsing pop quiz:
<script>document.write("<plaintext>Filler"); document.close()</script>
What does the DOM look like after document.close?
broken?
does broken count? :)
No :)
Is it not just <plaintext>Filler?
gsnedders: The theory is that it is not
The theory might be wrong :)
(biab)
jgraham: <html><head></head><body><plaintext>Filler</plaintext></body></html>
jgraham: (I didn't cheat. That is, I didn't actually try running your snippet.)
hum
no script tag?
seems like that would still be in the dom
Well, yeah. But I'm not convinced that's the interesting part. :P
i'm not sure whether we've properly handled all the document.close() cases
oh. I misread. I though the calling code was outside the document itself given .close()
especially with synchronous script execution with nested insertion points
exactly how synchronous it is is tricky
but this isn't one of those cases
The theory is that the document.close() does nothing and, at the point it is called there is no <plaintext> in the DOM because EOF has not yet been reached
(If this theory is true the results of nesting the whole construct inside a document.write of its own would be interestingly different)
jgraham: why wouldn't both the plaintext element and its child text node be already in the DOM at the point of calling .close()?
jgraham: I thought the spec changed to require that
jgraham: I expect it's even tested on html5test.com
hsivonen: The theory could be wong, like I said, but I thought it only got emitted on EOF
*wrong
Oh, no, that seems right
OK, so the original case I was looking at is more complex
Maybe the more complex is needed
goes spec hunting
Right, I oversimplified
Or..
More thinking less typing
Right
<script>document.write("<table><plaintext>Filler"); document.close()</script> was the original case
more or less
And in this case at the point of document.close the dom should have the <plaintext>, the <table> but *not* the string "Filler"
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/673
<table> is a neat way to make some content load later but appear earlier in the dom
too bad it's invalid to do that :)
Where "neat" in this case mean "non-interoperable and weird"
it'll soon be interoperable
oooh 11 alpha
http://addons.labs.opera.com/addons/extensions/
hmm, wonder why the background and canvas examples don't work in opera in http://blog.dholbert.org/2010/10/svg-as-image.html
sorry
wrong channel
hello
still not published
hmm
later today?
Re: Shane's email, shouldn't one want spec writers to go all Hixie?
hsivonen: which email?
hsivonen: I think "writing clear accurate specs" was not what he had in mind
I'm not sure what he *did* have in mind though
I assumed it was about him not advocating switching to an incompatible design that can be understood by more than 10 people in the world
ah, found link in the logs
yeah, I meant the link in the logs
hello, validators are telling me that im missing required attributes with `<style type="text/css">` - ive looked at the html5 spec but i dont see what im missing
any hints?
It probably means you need to move it into your <head>, if I remember correctly
ahh i do have one not in the head ...
(You can only use <style scoped> inside <body>, which is why it complains about the missing scoped attribute, I think)
wonders if the scoped feature will survive
yes, the validator wants to see the scoped attribute
jgraham: I doubt it
thanks guys
the attribute that's missing is scoped="" (since you put the style in body)
almost flying time yay
(but the problem is not that the attribute is missing, but that you put <style> in <body>)
yes it was a mistake from old code
didnt think i had any of those left
so http://twitter.com/#!/hsivonen/status/28004974377 seems to imply you might be working on releasing a standalone version of the gecko/vnu HTML5 parser
which would be very cool
if that is in fact a goal
hsivonen: libxml2
MikeSmith: not working but planning without any promise or commitment or schedule
wonders what C or C++ people use to convert various encodings into UTF-8
hsivonen: OK, understood
libiconv looks surprisingly bad
I was about to say…
I think that is what most use
handles XML in C++ via a system that first uses libxml2 to convert the XML to a custom binary format, and then the rest of the application uses a custom API to read that custom binary format
hsivonen: Getting a real HTML parser into libxml2 would be amazingly awesome
it has the same API design error that causes Gecko to be unable to detect an incomplete byte sequence right before EOF in multibyte encodings
it being libiconv
well, somebody should fix that
AFAICT, ICU converts to UTF-16
since iconv is in fact used all the hell all over the place
it's probably easier to fix Gecko's internal APIs than to fix the libiconv public API
libxml2 does rely on iconv
for example
(it's also possible that I have misunderstood the libiconv API)
I think
(I meant I think libxml2 relies on iconv)
MikeSmith: yeah, I guess there's no point in trying to fight libiconv if one isn't using ICU
it may be that libiconv is broken by design that way
just thinking out loud
for compat of some kind
I guess that large parts of the FOSS platform may also be in that state
like the Web platform
indeed
crap we are effectively stuck with forever
Like commercial platforms too
or for a long time at least
Philip`: true
that's a given
everything's crap, and we're stuck in it
but that's their problem
Like most non-computer-related platforms, too
Philip`:  such as?
zcorpan: you have given me my translation target for the day
Like TV, and electricity, and road systems, and book publishing, and all sorts of things, I guess

after university, I haven't written normal C or C++ code at all. I've been writing on top of all this Mozilla-specific infrastructure, so I don't really know how people really do stuff like stream io outside the Mozilla land
but I imagine no one really writes big apps in the io style shown in Stroustrup's book
They're stuck with suboptimal designs because there's lots of interacting parties and it's too expensive to change them all at once
I think DV addressed the broken dependency problem by reinventing a lot of wheels
hsivonen: Most non-trivial projects seem to make up their own project-specific infrastructure, so there isn't any "normal"
libxml2 seems to have a lot of stuff that it could be relying on libraries for
wow
zcorpan: Allt är skit, och vi är fast i den.
zcorpan: does that sound natural?
seems to round-trip at least
oh
wait
"stuck _in_ it"
hmm
not quite the same at all
though still a good sentiment
Good C++ library design usually seems to involve having as few dependencies as possible, to minimise friction with whatever crazy infrastructure is already used in projects
e.g. don't use any libraries for IO (even standard iostreams), just let the application provide a simple callback function
(then add an extra layer of convenience API that takes a filename and does sensible default behaviour)
it seems to me that java.io and org.xml.sax have a lot of value even when they suck
Yeah, C++ is pretty rubbish at having standard ways to do simple things like that
You can't even write a library that uses standard new/delete without some applications considering it unacceptable and requiring a way to override the behaviour
Philip`: I realize my previous experiences in working on proprietary commercial software does exhibit exactly what you describe
worked a lot at one time on product dev or e-mail infrastructure - MTA, message store, DB interfaces, congestion control stuff, related ldap server, other stuff
somebody should write a book about this
along the lines of Mythical Man Month
notes that Gecko supplies its own malloc on Windows and Linux and then puts a customized operator new on top of it
when I worked we used some third-party malloc
which we had licensed
tries to remember the name
very common one
but it was a give that using the platform malloc was a non-starter
*given
Mozilla uses jemalloc
isn't Lea malloc the other one people like to use?
SmartHeap is what we used
I think
actually, we had our own branch of it
that we maintained as part of our code
we licensed in and forked it basically
further example of the phenomenon Philip` was describing
I'd love to see some kind of tutorial that explains the memory management options for local name strings in the libxml2 DOM
hsivonen: cool to see you interested in libxml2; I may be able to help starting mid next month
rubys: to set expectations correctly: I'm just trying to find out what steps are required. I don't promise to take those steps at any particular schedule or at all.
rubys: of course, it would be awesome if you did :-)
I'm rather surprised that neither libxml2 nor Xerces C++ has a special interned type for local names
both Gecko and WebKit do interning around this area
hmm. I see that libxml2 docs say something about a dict for names
maybe there's optional interning or something?
I do a lot of HTML parsing.  Example which helps me keep track of issues and bugs: http://intertwingly.net/stories/2010/10/21/libxml2-html5-test.rb
wrong link
http://intertwingly.net/stories/2010/10/21/wgstatus.rb
example output: http://intertwingly.net/stories/2010/10/21/wgstatus.html
of course, that depends on being able to parse HTML, and most of the HTML I parse is "mostly" clean
ooooh http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#releasenotes/Java/JavaSnowLeopardUpdate3LeopardUpdate8RN/NewandNoteworthy/NewandNoteworthy.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40010380-CH4-DontLinkElementID_2
I'm also surprised at how few word are used to talk about the memory management / object ownership considerations in the libxml2 docs
"As of the release of Java for Mac OS X 10.6 Update 3, the version of Java that is ported by Apple, and that ships with Mac OS X, is deprecated."
back to the link I incorrectly posted at first, that is a test of the parser, and here is output: http://intertwingly.net/stories/2010/10/21/libxml2-html5-test.out
not all of those differences are problems, but most are
makes me wonder if I'm clueless and libxml2 DOM memory management is obvious for everyone else
http://xmlsoft.org/xmlmem.html
rubys: that page doesn't really explain if its possible to share local name memory between nodes and such
Author of libxml2 seems active: http://mail.gnome.org/archives/xml/2010-October/thread.html
look for Daniel Veillard
of course, the easy way would be not to care and use the node creator that always copies the local name
get it working, and then fix the problems that are real problems later
hsivonen: just wondering, what are you doing?
smaug____: I'm looking at the libxml2 tree API to get an idea what it would take to target the Java to C++ translator to target libxml2 in addition to targeting NSPR/Gecko
hsivonen: ah, so the idea is that libxml2 could support html5 parsing
smaug____: the idea is the have a library that does HTML5 parsing and is API-compatible with libxml2
(maybe sometime in the future when Firefox 4 has shipped, etc.)
with emphasis on "maybe"
MikeSmith: Allt är skit, och vi sitter fast i det
zcorpan: thanks
tweets
first I was inclined to correct MikeSmith with s/den/det/ but then I figured 'den' was right. But apparently 'det' would have been right anyway.
remembers now that hsivonen speaks Swedish too
MikeSmith: for *very* small values of "speak"
heh
all the Finns speak Swedish, well at least a bit
had a notion that s/den/det/ was better but has embarassingly bad Swedish
so a new ARIA document is published...
I'm still waiting for answers to my previous series of comments
hsivonen, http://i.imgur.com/51f9p.jpg is great
annevk: And the truth
just found http://www.w3.org/Style/css2-updates/russian/Overview.html
Look, someone found a bug in XHTML1
"To be or not to be" - William Shakespeare ... what is the proper HTML5 markup for this?
I used to think it was blockquote+cite, but based on #the-blockquote-element in the spec it would seem not to be.  Anyone around here know?
To be or not to be - William Shakespeare ... what is the proper HTML5 markup for this?
Williams Shakespeare does not receive a cite, all right.
a cite?
Yes, a cite, #the-cite-element
ah, correct. <cite> is for titles of works.
Yay for bruce muddling the waters again
not for authors? got it.
So it turns out bidi is complicated.
let's go shopping!
AryehGregor: no kidding
what made you realise that?
Aharon's comments on the dir=auto thing.
I'll have to take some time to read them carefully.
I'm pretty sure his proposal isn't ideal, but I doubt mine is so great either.
ah
i wish those bugs started from use cases rather than proposals
though we seem to be getting better on that front now
This is what you get from task forces.
The word "tak force" always makes me think that camouflage paint should be involved somewhere
*task
"Task Force" always reminds me of the route we did not take
Okay, my number-one desired feature right now is that browsers sync history and passwords and stuff between different vendors' browsers.
Is anyone interested in that, like, at all?
AryehGregor: define "anyone"
"anyone who actually stands a chance of encouraging it to happen"
AryehGregor: there's probably not a lot of people who use browsers from different vendors regularly
so I suspect there is not a lot of demand
annevk: Well you it is disappointing that the reality often seems to be less "action man" and more "paralysed by self-imposed bureaucracy man"
Tons of people use IE at work and some other browser at home.
Also, it would let people try out other browsers more easily, that's the real point.
othermaciej: I believe something called XMarks did this
So if I want to try out Firefox 4, I don't have to be constantly distracted by having to go look up my login info.
(which is stored in Chrome)
AryehGregor: It seems like a hard problem and even harder to convince browser vendors to implement
jgraham: Yeah, but years of experience tell me that by the time I get close enough to the photos (or more normally, they get close enough to me), it's August and I don't care any more
jgraham, why is it much harder than intra-browser sync?
The stuff you're syncing is essentially the same cross-browser, no?
it's hard for intra-browser too
Well, yes, but clearly that's not *too* hard.
it's difficulty^N harder to get N browsers to do it in a compatible way
(ok i pulled that out of my behind, but the idea is sound)
it's even harder than normal since the user benefit is low so it's unlikely anyone will care enough to write a spec, etc8
On the other hand, if this were widely supported, browsers could scrap their code for importing all this stuff from other browsers, which they currently all have to write anyway.
And that's surely even more annoying and fragile, because they have to reverse-engineer the other browser's storage formats.
*shrug*
write a spec, get browsers to implement
I know the procedure.
